newsitem.title: FINLAND: U.S. NATO line may force Moscow policy shift.
newsitem.headline: U.S. NATO line may force Moscow policy shift.

text.p: Russia said on Thursday the United States' insistence on expanding NATO could force Moscow to review its foreign policy and strengthen links with countries like China, India and Iran.

"If NATO expansion goes ahead in the toughest and most negative scenario for us...Russia will be faced with a need to review its foreign policy priorities," Kremlin spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky told reporters.
"Our relations are developing well with China, India and on some questions with Iran and these partners hold a lot of possibilities for us."

Yastrzhembsky, who has been playing down expectations of success for the two-day summit between President Bill Clinton and President Boris Yeltsin, said a foreign policy review could take place if NATO refused to give guarantees that it would not move nuclear forces into new member states.

It has been widely reported that Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic are the favourites to win accession as new members of NATO. There has been no suggestion from NATO that it wishes to station nuclear weapons in the new member states.

Russia has said previously it would have to review its foreign policy priorities if NATO expansion goes ahead but it has not discussed specific countries before with whom it would seek to develop closer ties.
Washington insists that NATO expansion will take place and that the two leaders will have to agree to disagree at their summit in Helsinki.
